user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_digest_auth_calc_userhash:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_digest_auth_calc_userhash (enum MHD_DigestAuthAlgo3 algo3,
                               const char *username,
                               const char *realm,
                               void *userhash_bin,
                               size_t bin_buf_size)
{
  struct DigestAlgorithm da;
  enum MHD_Result ret;

  if (! digest_init_one_time (&da, get_base_digest_algo (algo3)))
    return MHD_NO;
  if (digest_get_size (&da) > bin_buf_size)
    ret = MHD_NO;
  else
  {
    calc_userhash (&da,
                   username,
                   strlen (username),
                   realm,
                   strlen (realm),
                   userhash_bin);
    ret = MHD_YES;

#ifdef MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR
    if (digest_ext_error (&da))
      ret = MHD_NO;
#endif /* MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR */
  }
  digest_deinit (&da);

  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of memcmp or any code that compares null-terminated strings via memcmp in the provided function. The only string operations are strlen(username) and strlen(realm) (used to pass explicit lengths to calc_userhash), and there are no strcmp/memcmp/byte-wise comparisons of C strings in this snippet. The binary buffer userhash_bin is handled via a size check (digest_get_size (&da) > bin_buf_size) rather than by comparing null-terminated strings.

Note: functions called from this snippet (calc_userhash, digest_init_one_time, digest_get_size, digest_deinit, digest_ext_error) are not shown; their internal implementations could potentially use memcmp incorrectly, but those implementations are outside the provided code and therefore cannot be flagged here. If you want those inspected for Rule 21.14, provide their source.
